Discussions.Discussion_Name: Issue of Normalized Difference Snow Index (NDSI) from Lab05

Messages.Author: Tom Oswald Burgert
Messages.Content: Dear students,  After a student accidently used the river patch instead of the snow patch for the compuation of the Normalized Difference Snow Index (NDSI) and realized that also parts of the river where indicated as potential snow by the NDSI, I did some further research to contextualize this phenomon (extracts from scientific papers):  The use of NDSI has been widely used in mapping snow, however the reliability of such maps is often compromised by its reflectance similarity with other cover types like water, shiny rock surfaces and even vegetation covers. [...].  To address this issue, a near-infrared reflectance value greater than 0.11 can be used to mask out water pixels so as to improve NDSI classification accuracy.  So in short, the intuition that we have developed during the class was quite correct, bright reflectance values can be confused with snow by the NDSI.  I hope this clarification can help in your understanding of vegetation indices.  Best, Tom

Messages.Author: Felix Kleinsteuber
Messages.Content: Hi, I have come up with the following questions:  Regarding lecture 11 (unmixing): - Which or how many of these models are we expected to know during the exam? - Regarding NMF-QMV (slide 14): Could you please repeat in what way the terms written in the table correspond to the minimization goal above? Do we just substitute B and O with the terms in the table? If so, do we always select a single penalty (center, TV or boundary)? What do we substitute for "Extremes"? - Regarding tensor models (slide 17-18):     - Could you please repeat the idea. Is the advantage just interpretability (if yes, how so), performance or something different entirely?     - What do we call K?     - I don't know anything about CPD and Tucker decomposition. Is this relevant? - Regarding notation: Is there a meaningful difference between A and X? A seems to be used more for supervised and blind unmixing and X for sparse unmixing, however, in SUnSAL, SUnAA, and FASUN, A is used again. - Regarding SUnSAL (slide 19): What are D_h, D_v?  Generally, I would like to know which type of tasks we can expect (multiple choice, short answers, explanations, calculations, drawing, etc.) and if you have any example tasks for us. Thank you.

Messages.Author: Behnood Rasti
Messages.Content: Hi, 1- You don't have to memorize the formulas for unmixing models. You need to know the difference between three main categories, semisupervised, blind (unsupervised), and supervised. If you see a model you should be able to recognize if it is semisupervised, Blind, or supervised and why. For the NN models you should know the main concepts such as how to enforce the ASC and ANC what are the abundances and endmemebers. 2-B and O are given in the table should be substituted with in the LS-based optimization. It does not make sense to apply all Geometrical-based penalty at the same time. So one geometrical penalty is enough but you may apply penalties on abundances as well. Geometrical endmember based extraction/estimation techniques such as VCA and SiVM can be used for extracting extremes or boundary points. 3- Tensor models do not ignore the spatial correlation. Linear Mixing Model (LMM) works with vectorized data while Tensor Models assume HSI is a third order tensor. 4-CPD and Tucker decompositions are not interpretable for unmixing. You will not be asked about these two models. Because they are not explained in the slides. 5- X is a redundant matrix containing the abundances and often used for sparse unmixing but A is a low-rank matrix and can be used for all types of unmixing. 6-D_h and D_v are horizontal and vertical difference operators, respectively, for a vectorized image. But You do not have to know the details about them since they are not mentioned in the slides. For the exam please see the sample.

Messages.Author: Aleksandar Maksimovic
Messages.Content: *Hint: You may interpolate the data to 60m resolution to speed up the classification process and ease the process. You only need to interpolate the data if the respective band is not already in the desired resolution.*You only need to interpolate the data if the respective band is not already in the desired resolution.*  Do I even need to interpolate, if Bands 1-12 (except 8 and 10) are already available in 60m resolution? Just to clarify, as I'm a bit confused.  Thank you!

Messages.Author: Leonard Wayne Hackel
Messages.Content: You only need to interpolate the data if the respective band is not already in the desired resolution.

Messages.Author: Aleksandar Maksimovic
Messages.Content: So by desired solution, you mean the 60m, right? It's just linguistically confusing. :)

Messages.Author: Leonard Wayne Hackel
Messages.Content: If you want to use 60m resolution, then yes. You could also use bands with higher resolution (after interpolating* the ones that are not available in the higher resolution).  *we use interpolation for up- and downsampling in this homework, although it is technically not correct. Only upsampling is the correct linguistic equivalent of interpolation, but up- and downsampling are both called interpolation in software libraries such as pytorch. This is done for practical reasons, as from an implementation perspective, there is only a minor difference in downsampling (resampling with, e.g. scale 0.5, going from 120x120 to 60x60 pixels / going from 10m to 20m) and upsampling (resampling with, e.g. scale 0.5, going from 120x120 to 240x240 pixels / going from 10m to 5m). This is also the reason why there sometimes is no distinction, e.g. at https://www.sentinel-hub.com/faq/what-downsampling-and-upsampling/.

Messages.Author: Leonard Wayne Hackel
Messages.Content: Dear students, as promised, here the solution to the in-course practice from today: # already present in notebook threshold = 120 img_B_eq_thres = np.where(img_B_eq < threshold, 0, 255) # convert threshold to binary True/False mask keep_indicator = img_B_eq_thres > 0 # !! This does not work, as keep_indicator is (600, 600), but adj_img is (600, 600, 3) adj_img_masked = np.where(keep_indicator, adj_img, 0) # we need to add an axis to the keep_indicator, so that automatic broadcasting in numpy works adj_img_masked = np.where(keep_indicator[..., np.newaxis], adj_img, 0) # we could also use something like "np.expand_dims(keep_indicator, axis=-1)" to add the channel axis # now it works and we ca display the result # use previously adjusted histogram image to display the values imshow(adj_img_masked)   If you want to copy, there is also a Github Gist available. Best, Leonard Hackel - IP4RS Team

Messages.Author: Aleksander Maksymilian Krasowski
Messages.Content: Hey, I would say that the easiest way would be to simply download it via your Browser. I suppose the problem is that ISIS needs you to be logged in, in order to access the file (note that you are being forwarded to /login/index.php).  If you really want to download it via your shell you can also open up the Web Developer Tools inside your Browser, switch to the Network Tab. Once this is open click on the Download link to Lab01.ipynb on the ISIS page. You should be now able to see a GET request in the Network tab with status 200 (OK) for the file. Now you can go hit right-click -> Copy Value -> Copy cURL.  This will include the session-cookie (i.e. your login). Copying this into your shell and appending "-o Lab01.ipynb" (i.e., "please output this into a file named Lab01.ipynb") should download the notebook in a more hacky manner.  Hope this can help
